title: meghan markle prince harry private life
story: Darting like a madman into the rear gates at Windsor Castle.He could barely wait for the gates to clang shut behind him, while Prince Charles and Camilla were “secretly” piped in overhead on Saturday by helicopter, however that is done.Outside the castle, bedraggled peasants thronged in the hope they might catch a tiny glimpse of the royals at Archie’s christening, the very Baldricks Prince Harry had once happily welcomed ahead of his “people’s wedding” just over a year ago.He wanted , plebs at his rousty-jousty, knights’n’ laydeez, It’s A Royal Bonkout-themed festival of inclusivity, didn’t he I remember thinking the whole thing felt a tad King John. But I had no idea how sneeringly “modern feudal” the whole circus was about to become.What a dismal little VIP gathering Archie’s christening has turned out to be. A PR disaster.Harry and Meghan insisted on conducting the whole thing in secret, refusing even to reveal who his godparents were.I don’t even care who they are —they are Robbie Williams or that plastic Canadian friend of Meghan’s who looks like a Love Island reject, I’d rather not know.But why make such a snitty point of it unless he’s trolling the very people who admire him It seems so unjoyful — the opposite of what a christening is meant to be.I know what his arguments are. He wants a “normal” le for Archie. He hates the Press and the paparazzi.But the truth is the royals get a huge amount of privacy. They have far more privacy than the average citizen.They are not snapped while picking their noses at a newsagent. They are not filmed going on holiday. No one knows where they go on holiday or even where they are when they are not performing their duties.No one sells stories on their private lives or punts pictures. No one takes pictures or follows them at all, because no newspaper would carry the images.Eventhey are spotted by someone, they have huge security teams, paid for by us, to keep us at bay.The royals do not want privacy, they want a private le in public, and no one has the right to that.In spite of this, Harry appears to have gone what I would describe as the full Hugh Grant. Last week it turned out that the actor has become so obsessed with the idea that the paps were following him he confronted an Italian official who was innocently filming rubbish dumped in the street.Everywhere Harry looks, he sees people who want to take advantage of him, which is not true and leads to this sad irascibility in which he forgets what is kind and decent —  and who is paying the bill.What has become of him  If you scan Meghan and Harry’s Instagram feed, you will see how distant the “people’s prince” has turned out. There is no shortage of cloying information on how much he “cares” about alpacas and Mothering Sunday and advancing his sanctimonious “monthly social awareness approach” on mental health or climate change. But it is extra-ordinary how detached from reality the whole thing feels — it is a syrupy, fantasist’s medley of posturing sub-Beyoncean baloney about animals in “gap yah” locations.But does he really care about any of this stuff It is almost ashe has picked a selection of vague, non-committal subjects specically engineered to give no idea what he is thinking, like Leonardo DiCaprio.The overall effect is truly insincere.While it is clear Harry loves the royal tradition of virtue-signalling, it is obvious he does not enjoy being a royal at all. In fact, he dislikes being royal so much, he has waved through this shell of a person called “Prince Harry” operated by an American marketing droid who writes about “sharing” Harry’s “environmental POV”.There are half a million likes for a snap of the prince looking bored.Meghan has similarly vanished.If she had her way, it would not even be a christening, but a naming ceremony with fire pit curators and celebrity mixologists and D-list actresses as earth parents .She is so embarrassing I wonderedit was the godparents who had actually begged for privacy — you can just imagine Beyonce weighing up whether a second-tier royal christening was cool enough for her to openly acknowledge it.And so we have it: A royal christening in a building we paid for, conducted by a bishop whose salary we help foot, featuring royals whose lives we bankroll, in clothes we have paid for, sitting on seats we bought, waited on by staff we fund, with celebs who are not even sure they want to put their name to it.And they think they can say, “Oh, we’re not telling you anything about it” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: babys parents left unanswered questions
story: NewsBabys parents left with unanswered questions after inquest into tragic deathBaby Carter Cooksons parents had also lost their son Charlie when he was just two years oldShareByKatie Dickinson:,  JUL NewsCarters parents launched a desperate appeal to find him a donor heart "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe parents of a baby who lost their baby at just three weeks may never know the underlying cause of his death. Carter Cooksonaposs parents said they felt like they had been hit by a bus for a second time after an inquest into his tragic death. Three-week-old Carteraposs plight went public earlier this year when the tiny boy was born into a race against time for a new heart.But a suitable organ was never found and Carter, from South Shields, was just  days old when he died at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle on January , reports Chronicle Live .   Now an inquest has heard that after extensive tests and a post-mortem examination, the cause of the severe damage to his heart remains a mystery. Coroner Karen Dilks said Carter had suffered a sudden catastrophic event that caused damage to his heart around the time of his birth. But the underlying cause of it may never be known. The couple began dating in December  and settled into a happy relationship. But problems began after they argued with Emma Ravenscroft, also a neighbour. Kim said: Emma moved in about three years ago and at first we were friendly. She seemed nice and she borrowed stuff and stopped for a chat, as neighbours do. But then, she offered me money to clean her flat and I refused. I have worked as a cleaner in the past. After that, she got the hump with me and she was very off-hand. She was quite abusive in the street and I tried to avoid her. I started staying over at Dan’s house because he lived further up the street. But on December  last year, Ravenscroft’s car was vandalised – and someone daubed bad language in bleach on it.    She wrongly assumed that Dan and Kim were responsible. Kim said: “I have no idea who damaged her car but it certainly wasn’t me. “Dan and I had just watched a Christmas film and we were turning the lights off, ready for bed around pm, when there was a loud smash and glass flying everywhere. Dan was shouting that someone had smashed the living room window and then we heard banging and screaming at the front door. When the police sirens sounded, I was really relieved – I thought they were coming to help us.” But when the shocked couple opened their front door they were confronted by a line of armed police. Kim said: “They were screaming ‘Put your hands up!’ at Dan. It was horrendous. We were the victims and we couldn’t work out why they were arresting him.  But it was so scary, because they had guns, so we had to do as we were told. “It was only after Dan had been searched and handcuffed and the house was searched that we were told Emma had made a complaint that he had threatened her with a machete. “Of course we don’t have a machete. Dan is not that sort of bloke he would never hurt anyone. “We had CCTV so that was checked too – and of course it was clear. It was a totally wild goose chase.” Ravenscroft appeared before Stockport Magistrates last week. The court was told she made the call after she found someone had used bleach to write the word on the bonnet of her car. Armed police were scrambled to the scene but realised it was a hoax when Ravenscroft failed to end the  call and was overheard admitting she had made it up.  Ravenscroft was ordered to complete a -month community order and was also issued with a year-long restraining order, fined £ and ordered to pay £ costs. She was cleared of assaulting Dan and Kim. Cheshire Police confirmed several officers attended due to the mention of a machete — but no weapon was found at Danaposs home or in the surrounding area. An officer who attended said Ravenscroft had left the line open after the  call and was heard saying she was going to get him sent to jail. One of the armed PCs said: The use of the word aposmacheteapos prompts an armed response. Emma came out when we arrived and started shouting about what she said had happened. I went into her house with her.

story: NewsMeat label lies mean  in  products contain animal NOT stated on packetEXCLUSIVE: Six years on from the horse meat scandal fresh fraud sees dodgy meats being used in many products, Mirror probe revealsShareCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsMirror discovers that customers are still being ripped off with meats not stated on the packet "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSix years on from the horsegate scandal that shook Britain and the following ­crackdown, shoppers should feel ­confident their meat is what the label says it is. But the Mirror has discovered customers are still being ripped off, with one in five products containing cheaper cuts from dferent animals. The Food Standards Agency carried out  tests between June  and May  and found  items were contaminated with “unspecied meat or DNA species not declared on the label”. There was ham that contained no ham, lamb doner kebabs without a trace of lamb and pork sausages that also had lamb and beef in them.    Experts also insist Tory cuts to public services are allowing dodgy meat to get through as trading standards officers are too stretched to carry out tests. The Chartered Trading Standards Institute’s David Pickering branded the latest scandal a “fraud consumers can’t see”. He added: “How would you know that the ham in your sandwich is not really ham ” Which  strategic policy adviser Sue Davies said: “It is concerning , six years on from the horse meat scandal, consumers are still being misled about meat they are eating.  “The ­Government and local authorities must clamp down on food fraud.” The Local Government Association’s Simon Blackburn added: “Signicant funding cuts are affecting council services, which include trading standards budgets and staffing being cut by half.  “The ending of dedicated Food Standards Agency funding for food sampling has also made it very dficult to maintain sampling levels.” Our Freedom of Information request to the FSA found retailers, ­restaurants and caterers had meat products that were not properly labelled. In , products including supermarket beef burgers and ready meals were found to contain horse meat, sparking outrage and leading to supermarket shelves being cleared. A review ordered better testing along the supply chain. Anyone found mislabelling food can face up to two years in jail or an unlimited fine – or both.

title: selfless dying dad moved out
story: NewsSelfless dying dad moved out of the family home to shield his kidsMike Ryan, , was dying of leukaemia and told his family not to hold a funeral for him as he didnt want them under financial strainShareByHelen Johnson:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsMike wanted to shield his family from seeing how ill he was becoming "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devoted dad dying of cancer moved out of his family home to protect his young children from the pain of watching his terrible illness progress. The dad-of-two was only -years-old when he died in January, after a long fight with leukemia.Before he passed away, Mike told his family not to organise a funeral for him, because he wanted to spare them the cost of paying for it, reports the Manchester Evening News .His heartbroken family reluctantly decided to honour Mikeaposs wishes, and he had a simple cremation without a ceremony.    But they say that missing out on the chance to say a final goodbye has been incredibly hard. The dad-of-two, who lived in Baguley, was a full time carer for his son Charlie, , who has severe autism. He was so determined to shield Charlie, daughter Paige, , and partner Lauren from his illness that he even moved out of the family home into a flat towards the end of his le, so they wouldnapost have to see his health decline every day. But despite his failing health, he continued to care for his family right up until the day he physically couldnapost do it any more. Mikeaposs sister Gabby Gregory says everything he did was for other people, and he refused to let anyone spend money on a funeral. Gabby said: He faced it once and he beat it. We thought he would get better so we didnapost have time to save for it.    He wanted a non-ceremonial cremation so we had to respect his wishes, we had to come to that decision. He wouldnapost let anyone do it. My mum wanted to get a loan but he fully refused, he didnapost ever want to put that on anyone, he was such a good guy.  was harder than it all. Weaposll never have closure as a family. We never got to say goodbye. You canapost put that into words. Itaposs taken everyone a while to get back to work. Itaposs been so hard. Mike was first diagnosed with cancer in October  and following a bone marrow transplant and months of chemotherapy, he went into remission. But last August, the cancer came back and Mike was told he had between just two weeks and two months left to live. Gabby says he vowed to hang on for as long as he could, because he wanted to spend one final Christmas with his children. Mike made it to December, but sadly was in hospital on Christmas Day. But he woke up with a burst of energy on January  and was able to spend the day with his family, opening presents and celebrating with his children as he had wanted.

title: smoker who didnt know cigarettes
story: NewsSmoker who didnt know cigarettes cause cancer diagnosed with mouth tumourCaroline Stears, , from Truro, Cornwall, had had to have the tumour removed and gruelling radiotherapyShareCommentsByHarriet WhiteheadJane Lavender:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsCaroline didnt know smoking could cause oral cancer "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Ex-smoker Caroline Stears has a powerful message for anyone struggling to give up cigarettes - quit now before it kills you.The -year-old thought nothing of a tiny mouth ulcer, despite smoking between  and  cigarettes a day.So she was devastated to be told she had stage three oral cancer and had to endure an eight-and-a-half hour operation to remove the tumour.Hotel cleaner, Caroline, then had gruelling radiotherapy, which she said cooked her insides and made swalling so dficult she could eat nothing but half a tin of soup for a month. She now has a speech impediment and a constantly dry mouth.    Caroline said: My message to other people after what Iaposve been through would simply be, ‘Don’t smoke and look after yourself.apos After starting smoking when she was just , the -year-old admitted she had been feeling run down but thought it was just work stress. She used over-the-counter treatments for her ulcer but when it didnapost improve went to see her GP. Caroline said: I still wasn’t worried. I thought it was a bad ulcer and something like cancer never ever crossed my mind. It was there for about three weeks, so I went to the doctor to seethey could prescribe anything. The GP looked at it and referred me to the oral department at Truroaposs Royal Cornwall Hospital. Still I didnapost think cancer. I thought they might need to cut it out and then it would be fine. Four weeks late her oral surgeon gave her the devastating news that her tumour contained cancer cells.  Caroline said: “Still I was completely oblivious, I always associated smoking with lung cancer, never mouth cancer. “When I got the results it was a real shock, I think I was in total denial and was convinced they had made a mistake. “I went home and frantically searched the internet trying to figure out what was going on. I think I went through the five stages of grief - denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance. “I looked up pictures of it and was totally horried.” She had surgery at the Royal Cornwall to remove the tumour in June , with the surgeon also removing a saliy gland and around  lymph nodes from her neck – five of which turned out to be cancerous. Caroline said: The operation lasted eight-and-a-half hours because they had to keep taking the tissue and sending it to the lab to seeit was cancerous, working away until they got to non-cancerous tissue. By the time they removed the tumour it was  to cm long. It was behind my tongue and between the floor of my mouth.” Doctors also discovered a hole in Carolineaposs mouth, which was allowing food and drink to go straight into her neck. She said: ! could feel drink going down my neck. It felt like air bubbling and I thought it was odd but I’d just had surgery and didn’t know it wasn’t normal,” she said.  “They fixed it but I spent three weeks on a gastric tube which I found really traumatising.” Caroline left hospital after three weeks and was able to eat and drink normally after five weeks, by which time she could swallow again too. But because the cancer had already spread to some of her lymph nodes, eight weeks after her operation she began a six week course of radiotherapy, targeting her tongue. She said: “It basically cooked me. The first two weeks were fine, but by week four I wanted to end it all. “I found it dficult to breathe and the inside of my throat felt like it had been burned. It was all swollen. I had lots of blisters inside my mouth which was agony. “From week five to eight I was able to drink about half a bottle of water a day, which was really painful and all I could eat was half a can of soup - which took me two hours - and a bit of watermelon. “I ended up losing three stone and at one point doctors said they would put a feeding tube in me. I was terried of the side effects of that and the impact it would have on my ability to swallow. “My mood was so low, I felt lethargic and dizzy all the time. I had to wear a special mask for radiotherapy which clips to the table and made me feel very claustrophobic.  I found the whole thing traumatising and have suffered with post-traumatic stress disorder because of it.” Now in remission, Caroline has toto hospital for regular six week check-ups, which will continue but gradually reduce over the next five years. She said: “I’m terried of the cancer coming back and killing me. I’ve spoken to people who have had it six times. I don’t think I’ll breathe a sigh of relief until I’ve had my last check up in five yearsapos time. “When I wake up I still have to do exercises with my neck every morning, because it’s really stf. I have to stretch it out, as it feels like concrete. “I have constant dry mouth because of the impact of radiation on my saliva glands, too. “And it’s left me with a speech impediment. Itaposs like a lisp which gets worse later in the dayI’ve been talking. I have to make a conscious effort to form certain words and even struggle to say my last name. “I find people look at my mouth when I’m speaking, because the left side of my face drops – asI’ve had a stroke.  “ButI hadnapost had the treatment I know I might not even be here today.” Doctors said it was unusual for someone her age to be diagnosed with this type of cancer and told Caroline smoking was a likely cause. She said: That same day I came home and smoked all my cigarettes until I felt really sick and then didn’t want to do it anymore. “I’ve not smoked since. It’s hard, as it’s the most stressful time of my le and normally I would be reaching for them, but I’m not going to. “Of course I regret smoking, but I have also spoken to a lot of people who have never smoked and still got cancer. There are other causes as well like drinking and obesity. “But nobody ‘deserves’ to get cancer and I try not to blame myself for it. “I would also advise people to check their mouths and make sure they know when something feels dferent. If you’re worried make sure to get it checked out. It’s better to go to the doctor and be told it’s a mouth ulcer rather than leave it too long giving it chance to spread.”

title: writers share seaside childhood memories
story: NewsWriters share seaside childhood memories as part of Mirrors holiday campaignAs Daily Mirror partners with the Family Holiday Association to give hundreds of kids a seaside break, Mirror writers remember their first sandy adventuresShareCommentsByNick Webster:,  JUL NewsChildren do like to be beside the seaside - and the Mirror wants to make sure they can"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA visit to the seaside is a wonderful part of every childhood - which is why we have launched our special summer appeal in conjunction with the Family Holiday Association this week. With your help we can give hundreds of children who’ve never been to the beach a holiday this summer. Maybe we forget the excitement of our first trip to the seaside… so to jog all our memories our brilliant writers have reminisced about the very first time they saw then sea! Kevin Maguire Blessed are those of us born by the seaside so it was as much a part of my childhood as a coal fire, glass milk bottles and the Daily Mirror. Golden sands, crashing waves and a shivery breeze blowing along the beach even in the hottest summers was a way of le. Mam would push the youngest bairn at any time in the pramalong the front with the older kids trailing behind. I can’t remember not seeing the sea so it’s painful to think one-in-every-five kids has yet to enjoy the relentless exciting power of tides coming in and going out. No sandcastle however high with moat no matter how deep is able to withstand waves heading up the beach. I love valleys, moors and mountains but nothing beats sea shores.  Sara Wallis To this day, my brother and I still refer to my -year-old grandmother as Grandma Boats. Or sometimes even just Boats. I’m not sure she’s thrilled about it, but what can you do  When I was little, she and my grandpa lived in Southend and the name stuck - even though she hasn’t lived beside the seaside for donkeys. So I was one of the lucky ones who visited the seaside on a regular basis. I don’t remember the moment I first clapped eyes on the sea as a tiny child, but I do remember walking along the beach, singing about the ‘Prom, Prom, Prom, Tiddely-om-pom-pom’. I also remember harassing my parents to visit Peter Pan’s Playground, Southend Pier’s er, top fun fair as it was known in the s. Freezing cold swimming  Soggy sandcastles  Fish and chips covered in sand  Most likely. But through these rose-tinted spectacles, they were the best days ever.    Anila Baig I must have been very small when I first went to Scarborough - I was young enough to wear a two-piece swimsuit - and I remember that everyone seemed in a good mood here in this magical place of sand and sun. It felt like I was in another country, I loved the feel of the sand under my feet and the smell of the sea air.  My dad rolled his trousers up and put a knotted handkerchief on his head and my brother and I built competing sandcastles. We would race giggling into the sea to wash ourselves then traipse back to our spot covered in sand again. When my niece was four she demanded we take her to the seaside- she was born in Japan- so we rocked up to Morecambe. It was about minus  and we nearly froze to death on the beach as we battled gales and tried to eat our sand encrusted fish and chips but, to my niece, it was the best day ever. She takes after me. Paul Routledge  I’m nearly three years old, with my mother on the sea front in Scarborough in . We came here on a train from pit-town Normanton, west Yorkshire, where the pigeons fly backwards so they don’t get coal dust in their eyes. All this lovely sand to play with my bucket and spade. The sea smells, it tastes bitter and it’s very cold. I don’t think I like it. The waves wrecked my castle.  We’re going back to our “digs” in St Sepulchre Street. Mam says we’re back to the beach tomorrow, andI’m good I can have some chips. With scraps. That makes up for having to paddle in cold water, where the sand scratches my toes. Mam says we’re lucky to be here, but she’s sitting among crowds of people and I’m scared I might lose her. And one day I did, and cried a lot. Bloody seaside, I bet she said.  Alison Phillips I’m not entirely sureit’s the first time I saw the sea.. but it’s definitely the first time I remember feeling the sea washing around me, as I tried to learn to swim. We’d gone - as we did every year - for a day trip on Biss’s Buses with my grandma and grandad to Frinton On Sea. It’s that stretch of the Essex coastline deemedto be posher than Portofino because it didn’t have a pub. Or a chippie. I know!  You could spend six hours in Frinton just waiting for a stretch of beach to appear big enough to spread out our tartan blanket and those stripey nylon chairs which your legs stuck to and sliced your fingers off each time you put them down. But it was aways worth the wait. That summer’s day I was determined to learn to swim and had decidedI lay in the water long enough, sooner or later it would just ‘happen’. Sure enough, it didn’t. Just as surely I spent the next three days with acute sunburn on my back. It was  and suncream hadn’t been invented in Essex. More than  years ago I remember the fun and freedom of that sunny day as clearly as the sunburn which followed. It’s a tragedy and an outrage one in four Brit kids aren’t having days like those . Brian Reade

story: NewsHuge glacier is on the brink of melting and raising sea level by  inchesThwaites Glacier in Antarctica, measuring , square miles, could tip Earth towards catastrophe as it is set to break up entirelyShareCommentsByAmy-Clare Martin:,  JUL NewsThwaites Glacier in Antarctica is set to raise sea levels in "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA huge glacier is at risk of crossing a tipping point which could cause a catastrophic in rise in global sea levels, scientists have warned. Thwaites Glacier, in Antarctica, is heading towards an “instability” which, once reached, means it could all float out into the open ocean within just  years. The resulting sea-level rise would be two-and-a-half times bigger than the .in increase since pre global-warming levels of the late th century, a NASA-funded study found. NASA scientist Dr Helene Seroussi said: “After reaching the tipping point, Thwaites Glacier could lose all of its ice in a period of  years.    “That would make for a sea-level rise of about half a metre.” Thwaites, measuring , square miles, is among five glaciers to double their rate of ice loss in six years, according to the National Science Foundation. The dire prediction came after  ice-flow models of the glacier all predicted the instability would be ­triggeredthe rate of ice melt due to ocean warming stays at current levels. Dr Seroussi said a glacier becomes unstable when warmer sea water reaches land which slopes downwards, adding: “The process becomes self-­perpetuating.”

title: arthur rides 1000 miles from perth to germany in memory of tragic tayside girl harlow
story: His bike is nowhere near as quick as the super sporty cars he looks after in Tayside as workshop controller at Porsche.But Arthur Booth nevertheless chose to use two wheels instead of four to ride the , miles from the Perth Porsche premises, which is part of the Peter Vardy Group, to the German company’s HQ in Stuttgart to raise money for a very worthy cause.The -year-old has raised nearly £, for the Harlow’s Helping Hand fund which has been set up in memory of Coupar Angus toddler Harlow Edwards who died after being knocked down by a car in the town in October .The fund helps bereaved parents who have lost young children by providing support for funeral and headstone costs.Arthur said: “It took me nine days to get there.“I set off from Perth to Whitley Bay on the north-east coast of England then went down to York and King’s Lynn. From there I caught a ferry from Harwich to Rotterdam and made my way to Stuttgart via Den Bosch and Venlo, which are also in Holland, and on to Koblenz, Mainz and Mannheim in Germany before ending up in Stuttgart.“Once there, I saw round the Stuttgart factory and museum before coming home by train.”Arthur decided to undertake his gruelling journey for Harlow’s Helping Hand as a former colleague had been helped by the fund.He added: “Along the way people asked me why I was cycling such a distance so I told them about Harlow and they kindly donated money. Raising money for charity is one of the things my company does as a way of giving something back to the community.“This isn’t the first long distance bike ride I have completed.“I have previously cycled from Land’s End to John O’Groats with the money I raised going to a charity in Edinburgh named The Yard which raises cash for adventure playgrounds for disabled children.”

title: benjamin siegrist looking to make history as he aims for top flight place
story: Benjamin Siegrist was flattered to be linked with a move to the English Championship over the summer.But other than to the Premiership with Dundee United, the Swiss goalkeeper isn’t planning of going anywhere for quite some time.Siegrist’s performances in the second half of last season, culminating in a string of five-star displays during the promotion play-offs, saw him watched by Nottingham Forest.That was nice to hear as he enjoyed a few weeks off last month but, as he focuses on the coming season with the Tangerines, fans will be delighted to learn it’s not turned his head.“It was nice but it just proved the point to me I know what I can do and I know where the standards lie,” he said.“I am more than happy here. I know what I have here and I work well with the staff.“I know how big a club this is and I am really happy to be here.“And what is important for me is I want to be one of those players who go in the history books of this club and say he was one who got promotion for the team.“I want to improve and learn every week. As a team I think we got better last season as the games continued and I think I got better as a goalkeeper.“We want to keep doing that this year and,we do, we will get back to where we want to be.“Everybody knows where this club belongs and everybody wants to be part of achieving that ultimate goal of getting promoted.“That’s a big point of incentive and motivation for all the players.”Siegrist admits a bonus for him as he ed to work last week was teaming up again in training with fellow-goalie Deniz Mehmet.He was at United until January and has ed with a view to signing up again.“We crossed paths before when we were younger, at international tournaments with Switzerland and Turkey.“Coming from clubs down south we also faced each other. We are competing for the same place but there is always the goalkeepers’ union that means we stick together and it is nice to be working every day with someone you like.”Very much one for looking forward, Siegrist refuses to dwell too long on the disappointing end to last term that saw United again miss out on promotion in the play-offs.And when he does look back, he takes the positives.“I think what happened last year is part of our motivation for this year but I don’t want to speak too much about it because we start from zero again for a new season.“You do every year. In terms of experience it is good that we have had big games, big occasions together and that will help us.“It is like money in the bank but this season is about doing it consistently and picking up points over the whole of the year.”Tonight sees the start of a busy weekend when the entire squad will be involved in a friendly at Brechin before heading for Dumbarton tomorrow to do it all again.Two games in less than  hours may seem unusual but, for Siegrist, it will be the perfect way to prepare for the start of the competitive action in the Betfred Cup at Hearts next week.“So far as fitness goes we are good and game time is the most valuable time you have as a player,” he added.“You can train all week butyou don’t have a game at the end of it you are not bringing everything you’ve worked on together.“It is good to have as many games as we can so we are looking forward to these two games.“There is a lot more to football than passing and running, so game time is the most valuable part of pre-season.”

title: girl 13 taken home by cops after being caught drinking in north east town
story: Police had to take a -year-old girl home after she was found under the influence of alcohol during an operation in a north-east town.And two other boys were caught with cannabis at separate locations in Stonehaven during a patrol with Mackie Academy head teacher Louise Moir on Saturday night.The object of the operation was to crack down on youth disorder, antisocial behaviour and underage drinking at the start of the school holidays.No other incidents were detected during the patrol.Local Sergeant Chris Smith said: #Although Stonehaven has very low levels of anti-social behaviour issues involving young people, we want to ensure this trend continues.#The local policing team at Stonehaven along with our partners at Mackie Academy are committed to ensuring that young people enjoy their holidays safely and without disrupting local residents.“Patrols will continue over the summer holidays as part of our longer term strategy aimed at reducing youth disorder, anti-social behaviour and other acts of criminality and I continue to urge residents to report issues to the Police.#I would also like to take this opportunity to ask parents and s to ensure they know where young people are going and what they are up to # by working together we can all ensure Stonehaven remains a very welcoming place to live.#Head teacher Louise added: “I am pleased Mackie Academy joined forces with our local police team to work in partnership in keeping Stonehaven safe.“I am hopeful that working together in this way will encourage Mackie Academy pupils to be excellent ambassadors for the school and Stonehaven.#I would like to thank the police officers who gave me a valuable insight into their day-to-day work when I accompanied them on a patrol.”

On Friday, the Dice Ceilidh Band warmed up the drenched crowd with feverish dancing to traditional music, before Massaoke got everyone singing at a karaoke session with a -piece band playing the classics.Saturday#s headliners Bombskare, #the undisputed masters of Scottish reggae#, delivered a bouncing, infectious dance sound for their latest trip to FyneFest. title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

title: improving attitudes to health
story: Barabel McKayUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsLast year we were studying the Argyll and Bute Health and Social Care Partnership#Transforming Together#   document, which presented a vision of combining our will and skills to create a healthy future for the citizens of Argyll.The promises in that did not translate into reality.Now, a  beautully constructed and presented Living Well document is available. It runs to  pages, and must have taken signicant time and money to produce.It relies heavily on community participation and the Third Sector Interface .While it was being prepared the HSCP was in the process of getting rid of volunteer forums, TSI was shedding staff and Guided Self Help was being transferred to the NHS Mental Health Team, while essential services are still dependent on successful bids for money.Planning must not be a substitute for provision. In Living Well we are told that hypertension is by far the most common long-term condition. This area lacks the yearly health checks which might lead to early detection and intervention.The initiative and enthusiasm of hospital staff in improving mobility have already been commended, but the dearth of professional rehabilitation services in the community is nothing short of a disgrace.Everyone  seems to recognise this # indeed at a recent housing conference the keynote speaker highlighted the need for intervention to halt the downward slide into dependency. In an English trust they have even  appointed a physiotherapist to identy reversible causes of frailty.We have to fight complacency about our own health and in the attitudes of our health care providers.To contact Mid Argyll Health and Care Forum, email the forum chairperson Barabel McKay at barabelmck@gmail

title: selkirk-rideout-to-support-scotts-tiny-changes
story: SELKIRKS Ex Standard Bearers are set to saddle up to boost a mental health charity formed in memory of Frightened Rabbit singer Scott Hutchison.The -year-old took his own le in  after struggling with mental health issues for many years.Scott left behind a musical legacy which continues to touch people around the world.And on the anniversary of his death in May, his brothers, Neil and Grant, and parents, Marion and Ron, launched the Tiny Changes charity in his memory.The remaining members of Frightened Rabbit released a tenth anniversary covers version of their seminal The Midnight Organ Fight album last month to benefit Tiny Changes.And now the town where Scott, Grant and fellow band member Billy Kennedy grew up is also backing the charity.All proceeds from the Ex Standard Bearers Associations charity ride on Saturday, August  will go to Tiny Changes.Scott Tomlinson, who is one of the organisers, told us: "Every year we discuss which charities we should support with the charity ride and when Tiny Changes was suggested everyone was in favour."Scott was a Selkirk boy and we want to remember him by supporting his charity."For the past six years, more than  riders have taken part in the Ex Standard Bearers charity ride.Thousands have been raised for local causes and organisations each year.Tiny Changes aims to raise awareness of children and young peoplersquos mental health issues, as well as advancing understandings of the root causes.The charity also wants to provide support and promote initiatives that help children impacted by mental health problems, along with their families and carers.All proceeds from the charity ride and the riders social evening which follows will benefit the charity.And a crowdfunding page has also been set up to compliment the event.Mr Tomlinson added: "We want to raise as much money as possible for this very worthwhile charity."Mental health is something that impacts so many people of all ages."The charity ride is a great challenge for riders and takes in some beautul scenery."Selkirk Standard Bearer Craig Monks will lead the -miles rideout along with Ex Standard Bearers James Cheyne, Stuart Coltherd and Mr Tomlinson.The cavalcade will take in the scenic Yarrow and Ettrick valleys as well as the rolling hills above Ashkirk.All riders will be asked to raise a minimum of pound sponsorship to take part.For further details about taking part contact Mr Tomlinson on  .

title: selkirk-high-to-log-on-first-in-ipad-rollout
story: PUPILS in Selkirk are set to be the first in the Borders to have classroom iPads.Scottish Borders Councils pound million Inspire Learning project has already started rolling out with teachers in all of the regions secondary schools being issued with the Apple devices.Following the summer holidays, Selkirk High pupils will all be issued with their own iPads.And they will be followed during the Autumn term by students at Kelso High, Hawick High and Earlston High.Teachers have been getting to grips with the new teaching methods throughout June.Selkirk art and design teacher Chris Dolan told us: ldquoI think this programme is going to see huge changes in teaching and learning - in the way I go about my lessons and plan for them as well as improving pupil engagement and even how pupils give me feedback on a piece of work theyrsquove been doing."I am really looking forward to the opportunity to start to use them in the classroom in the upcoming sessions.The iPad roll-out has come in for fierce criticism from parents and concerns continue over finances being taken from other school budgets to fund the devices.But many of the secondary school teachers who have undergone training sessions, have been impressed.Drama teacher Sam Swinton said: ldquoItrsquos something Irsquom really excited about."I think itrsquos going to open up a wealth of possibilities for our kids in terms of things like set design and performance evaluations."This is a great new chapter for drama in education.Pupils at Peebles High, Eyemouth High and Galashiels High will receive their iPads during the   winter term.And Berwickshire Highs devices will be delivered next year.Pupils in Jedburgh will be issued with iPads when their new school opens in the summer of .Peebles computing and business studies teacher Anne Delaney said: ldquoThe sessions have been really good."Inspire will make learning more accessible to all, with every pupil able to access materials both in the classroom and at home.The primary school roll-out will take place from next year.

title: council-told-school-library-pilot-not-been-a-good-experience
story: CONCERNS have been raised about the impact of removing librarians from school due to noise levels, disruption and children being left to police their own peers.Scottish Borders Council is currently running a pilot scheme at Galashiels, Peebles and Kelso high schools, which has seen pupils and volunteers replacing librarians.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Wednesday June , SNP councillor Andy Anderson, who represents Galashiels, told the chamber that the experience of pupils at Galashiels Academy has not been positive.He asked members of the ruling Tory Independent coalition: ldquoWe are about a year down the line in the pilot of librarian-less school libraries.ldquoWhat lessons have been learned from this from the schools taking part and how is this informing the future of our school libraries East Berwickshire councillor Carol Hamilton, who acts as the executiversquos member for children and young people, said: ldquoThe pilot in three high schools started in October . An interim evaluation took place in December  with minor changes being implemented in January  to address some minor issues.ldquoA more detailed evaluation was conducted in April  which provided useful feedback from students, staff and parents from all nine high schools.ldquoThe vast majority of respondents highlighted the importance of having access to a library for reading, digital, research and study.ldquoThe feedback has been analysed and options for realising the decision of previous council to identy savings is ongoing.ldquoIt will also be critical to ensure that future library provision needs to be equitable across the authority.To which councillor Anderson: ldquoFor Galashiels Academy this has not been a good experience. The school has reported to the parent council that the noise levels in the library has at times been disruptive to other library users and to nearby classes, and excessive litter has been left in the library.ldquoDespite a self-service system that is aimed to be straightforward to operate, books are not finding their way to their correct place in the library once they have been ed.ldquoS pupils have been tasked throughout the year to keep the library running, but they also have their own studies and other activities that they volunteer for.ldquoThe former library service provision has in effect been replaced with a service run by pupils with little or no training, who should not be left to police their peers.ldquoThe perception is that this is merely another cost-cutting exercise by Scottish Borders council with little or no obvious benefit to the pupils.ldquoThis experience has been similar in Eyemouth, in the memberrsquos own ward, and has been backed up by a detailed letter from the chair of Eyemouth Parent Council sent to her and other councillors.ldquoThis backs up the experiences at Galashiels Academy. Dare I say it, there appears to have been a lack of lsquoinspired learningrsquo in this process.ldquoSurely you must agree that it is time to abandon this ill-conceived pilot and get our school libraries back to being fully al centres for study and learning for the benefit of our pupils.In response, councillor Hamilton acknowledged that there are issues with the scheme at Galashiels Academy: ldquoLast night I went to Galashiels to watch their production of High School Musical and I did speak to the parent chair, and I am aware of the issues and we are addressing them.ldquoThere are still a report to come about the libraries and wersquore having to look at each library as each library is dferent in terms of its layout, and the building.ldquoSome schools are looking a dferent service from their schools sothere is anything further Irsquoll come back to you.

title: roads-firm-to-rewrite-signs-following-tourist-u-turns
story: CONTRACTORS behind a closed road near the Grey Mares Tail have been forced to rewrite their signs.Because of Openreach cabling being laid near Moffat, the A road to Selkirk is closed in both directions for  days.The daytime closures, between am and pm, started this week.And businesses in the Yarrow Valley have already reported a major downturn in trade.Although the closure on the Dumfries and Galloway side of the local authority boundary was expected to lead to a drop in visitors from the south-west, misleading signs from the other end of the road have hurt retailers and hoteliers further.Closure signs placed in Selkirk, Traquair, Innerleithen, Tweedsmuir and at other minor roads leading onto the A dont indicate where the road is closed.And, according to business owners in the valley, many tourists are performing u-turns rather than making their ways up to the scenic St Marys Loch.On Monday morning, the Glen Cafe next to St Marys Loch had only served a handful of customers.At the nearby Gordon Arms staff were also twiddling their thumbs.Susan Cree from the Gordon Arms told us: "I went into Selkirk to see what the signs said and during the time I stopped there were two camper vans pulling up at the sign and about to turn around."They only continued up the valley after I told them where the road was closed."Weve already had cancellations from people who were intending travelling from the Moffat side, and we are a lot quieter today than we would normally be."We appreciate that things have to get done but this is our busiest time of the year - this -day closure is in the middle of the holiday season."Pre-warning signs about the closure led to businesses in the valley alerting Dumfries and Galloway to the misleading wording.And they were promised that changes would be made ahead of the closures.Susan added: "We wanted to lessen the impact as much as we could and the council said they would have the signage changed, but that hasnt happened."The sign at the crossroads outside the Gordon Arms is telling drivers not to go any further, yet there are businesses at St Marys Loch and the road isnt closed until beyond Grey Mares Tail."The A will be closed at Camp Cottage until next Wednesday at the earliest.Following complaints about the signs, Dumfries and Galloway held an emergency meeting with contractors.And they have promised that new signs will be erected.A spokesman for the local authority said: "A meeting has taken place with the contractor for the works on the A."Following this meeting, new signage is being placed on the route by the contractor as a matter of urgency."The new signage will reflect the time that the closure is in place and the exact location of the closure."

title: poppyscotland-welfare-service-marches-into-the-borders
story: POPPYSCOTLAND has launched a new service to transform the support available for the Armed Forces community in Scotland.And the Scottish Borders is one of the areas where the new, enhanced service will be available.The Welfare Support Service is open to the Armed Forces community across the country, but, crucially, it will have a strong local focus and will be tailored to the needs of each inidual.Looking after the Borders area is Welfare Support Officer Fiona Deacon.Fiona, who served for almost  years in the Royal Military Police and became the first woman to cast Colours during Selkirk Common Riding, told us: ldquoAs an Armed Forces veteran myself, I feel very privileged to be part of this new community-based beneficiary-focused service."I look forward to working in partnership with other service providers and charitable organisations to achieve the best possible results for our Armed Forces veterans and their families.The Welfare Support Service team will be made up of four Welfare Support Officers and two Independent Living Advisers, each working within a designated geographical area.The Welfare Support Officer will provide support to vulnerable veterans and to those identied as having complex needs.These could range from mental or physical health to problems with money and housing.As well as acting as the personal point of contact for Poppyscotlandrsquos clients, members of the new team will work alongside a wide network of agencies, professionals and volunteers to ensure that veterans in the Borders who require support get the help needed.Independent Living Adviser Mary Spence covers Glasgow, Lanarkshire, Forth Valley, Ayrshire, Dunbartonshire, Renfrewshire  Inverclyde, Argyle  Bute, Renfrewshire  Inverclyde, Dumfries  Galloway and the Scottish Borders.She said: ldquoI am delighted to be joining Poppyscotland in my capacity as an Independent Living Adviser, working alongside our partners to deliver person-centred services to our beneficiaries and their families.ldquoIn this, the th year since D-Day, it has never been more important or relevant to remember the sacrices made every day by our Armed Forces and, as importantly, their families, and the debt we owe them. We are already busy with referrals and have been able to provide advice, support and financial assistance to the Armed Forces Community across Scotland.To find out more information about Poppyscotlandrsquos new Welfare Support Service visit www.poppyscotland.org.uk get-help .
